ANS101.name: Professional Development in Animal Science I
ANS101.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
ANS101.description: Careers in animal science. Job application, portfolio development, interviewing, and resume development.
ANS101.restrictions: Open to students in the Animal Science major.

ANS110.name: Introductory Animal Agriculture
ANS110.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
ANS110.description: History of animal agriculture and its relationship to human needs, production systems, marketing, and environmental considerations. Current goals of and limitations affecting U.S. farm animal production. Field trips required.
ANS110.restrictions: Open to undergraduate students or agricultural technology students.

ANS110L.name: Introductory Animal Agriculture Laboratory
ANS110L.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
ANS110L.description: Hands on experience in working with farm and companion animals. Field trip required.

ANS111.name: Livestock Industries Seminar
ANS111.description: Academic and career planning and professional development in the animal agriculture industry.
ANS111.restrictions: Open to students in the Institute of Agricultural Technology.

ANS115.name: Meats Technology Clerkship
ANS115.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
ANS115.description: Hands-on experience in meat production. Hazard Analysis Critical Control Point (HACCP). Facility maintenance and sanitation. Personnel management.
ANS115.restrictions: Open to students in the Institute of Agricultural Technology.

ANS122A.name: Feedlot Clerkship
ANS122A.description: Clerkship to gain hands-on skills in the management of a working feedlot. Feeding cattle, feed storage, manure management, health programs, evaluation and selection of cattle, facilities maintenance, marketing fed cattle.
ANS122A.restrictions: Open to students in the Institute of Agricultural Technology.

ANS122B.name: Beef Cow Calf Clerkship
ANS122B.description: Clerkship to gain hands-on skills in the management of a working cow-calf farm. Feeding, reproduction, genetics, and selection, facilities maintenance, exhibiting cattle for sale and daily management skills.
ANS122B.restrictions: Open to students in the Institute of Agricultural Technology.

ANS124.name: Introduction to Sustainable Agriculture and Food Systems
ANS124.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
ANS124.description: Contemporary research and movements involving agricultural and food system sustainability. Socio-cultural factors influencing food and agriculture.
ANS124.restrictions: Open to undergraduate students or agricultural technology students.

ANS132.name: Dairy Farm Management Seminar
ANS132.description: Challenges and opportunities in the dairy industry.
ANS132.restrictions: Open to students in the Institute of Agricultural Technology.

ANS140.name: Fundamentals of Horsemanship
ANS140.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
ANS140.description: Safe horse handling skills. Riding skills. Riding aids and working with the horse at the beginner, intermediate or advanced level.

ANS140A.name: Fundamentals of Young-Horse Training
ANS140A.description: Demonstration and practice of safely working with and training weanlings, yearlings and two-year-old horses. Halter training and longeing techniques of clippers and bathing. Discussion of application of learning theory. Assist with young horse husbandry procedures.
ANS140A.restrictions: Open to students in the College of Agriculture and Natural Resources or in the Institute of Agricultural Technology or in the Department of Animal Science or in the Applied Horse Science Major or in the Horse Management Major.

ANS141L.name: Draft Horse Basics
ANS141L.description: Safe handling, hitching and driving of draft horses. Care and maintenance of harness and horse drawn equipment.

ANS142.name: Horse Training for Competition
ANS142.description: Training techniques to prepare horses for competition. Exhibiting horses.

ANS143.name: Principles of Trail Riding
ANS143.description: Selection, nutrition and conditioning of horses for recreational or competitive trail riding.

ANS144.name: Introduction to Horse Breeding and Foal Management
ANS144.description: Strategic development for horse breeding based on conformation and genetics, breeding the mare, prenatal and postpartum care.

ANS146.name: Fundamentals of Horse Training
ANS146.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
ANS146.description: Training and preparing an untrained horse for handling, riding and showing. Sale preparation.
ANS146.restrictions: Open to undergraduate students in the Institute of Agricultural Technology. Approval of department.

ANS147.name: Horse Management Placement Seminar
ANS147.description: Securing a placement training experience. Writing a resume.
ANS147.restrictions: Open to students in the Institute of Agricultural Technology.

ANS148.name: Methods of Instructing Safe Horsemanship
ANS148.description: Lesson planning and communication skills for riding instructors. Safety and legal issues. Riding instructor certification. Organizations.
ANS148.restrictions: Open to students in the Institute of Agricultural Technology.

ANS149.name: Horse Management Clerkship
ANS149.description: Management of a working horse farm. Feeding, reproduction, genetics, selection, facilities maintenance, and daily management skills.
ANS149.restrictions: Open to students in the Institute of Agricultural Technology.

ANS151.name: Poultry Production Clerkship
ANS151.description: Hands-on experience in poultry production, including nutrition, health, and reproduction. Housing. Records and personnel management.
ANS151.restrictions: Open to students in the Institute of Agricultural Technology.

ANS162.name: Sheep Production Clerkship
ANS162.description: Hands-on experience in sheep production, including nutrition, health, and reproduction. Housing. Records and personnel management. Environmental management.
ANS162.restrictions: Open to students in the Institute of Agricultural Technology.

ANS171.name: Swine Clerkship
ANS171.description: Hands-on experience in swine care. Nutrition. Housing maintenance. Health. Reproduction. Records management. Environmental management. Personnel management.
ANS171.restrictions: Open to students in the Institute of Agricultural Technology.

ANS200A.name: Introductory Judging of Livestock or Carcasses
ANS200A.description: Evaluation of functional conformation of beef cattle, sheep and swine and their carcasses. Preparation for intercollegiate competition. Field trips required.
ANS200A.restrictions: Not open to freshmen. A student may earn a maximum of 8 credits from ANS 200A, ANS 200C, ANS 200D, ANS 200E, ANS 200F, ANS 300A, ANS 300C, ANS 300D, ANS 300E, and ANS 300F.

ANS200C.name: Introductory Judging of Dairy Cattle
ANS200C.description: Evaluation of functional conformation of dairy cattle. Preparation for intercollegiate competition.
ANS200C.restrictions: A student may earn a maximum of 8 credits from the following courses

ANS200D.name: Introductory Judging of Horses
ANS200D.description: Evaluation of functional conformation and performance of horses. Preparation for intercollegiate competition.
ANS200D.restrictions: A student may earn a maximum of 8 credits from the following courses

ANS200E.name: Introductory Animal Welfare Assessment
ANS200E.description: Physiological and behavioral indicators of animal welfare. Quantitative measures and ethical issues. Written and oral assessments of animal welfare.
ANS200E.restrictions: A student may earn a maximum of 8 credits from the following courses

ANS200F.name: Dairy Farm Evaluation
ANS200F.description: Evaluation of dairy farm management. Preparation for collegiate competition. Field trip required.
ANS200F.restrictions: A student may earn a maximum of 8 credits from the following courses

ANS201.name: Animal Products
ANS201.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
ANS201.description: Edible animal products. Food safety. Preservation, storage and distribution of dairy, meat and egg products.

ANS201L.name: Animal Products Laboratory
ANS201L.description: Processing and evaluation of meat, milk and egg products.

ANS203.name: Principles of Livestock Feeding
ANS203.description: Feed nutrients, digestion and metabolism. Classification of feeds. Nutrient requirements for dairy and beef cattle, sheep, swine and horses.
ANS203.restrictions: Open to students in the Institute of Agricultural Technology.

ANS210.name: Introduction to Disciplines in Animal Agriculture
ANS210.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
ANS210.description: Problem solving and literature searches with realistic examples to demonstrate multi-disciplinary scientific solutions in Animal Science.

ANS211.name: Animal and Product Evaluation
ANS211.description: Evaluation of breeding stock, market animals and carcasses. Performance records and structural correctness of breeding animals. Quality grading, yield grading and pricing of market animals and carcasses.

ANS215.name: Growth, Health and Lactation in Dairy Cattle
ANS215.description: Mammary anatomy and growth. Immunization and biosecurity. Lactation and mastitis. Transition into lactation.
ANS215.restrictions: Open to students in the Institute of Agricultural Technology.

ANS222.name: Introductory Beef Cattle Management
ANS222.description: Management practices and systems for beef herds. Feed requirements, reproduction, breeding, performance testing, housing, and diseases. Costs and returns.

ANS224.name: Sustainable Farm and Food Systems Field Studies
ANS224.description: Field visits to farm and food system operations that utilize sustainable practices in Michigan. Offered first half of semester.
ANS224.restrictions: Not open to freshmen or agricultural technology students.

ANS225.name: Horse Behavior and Welfare
ANS225.description: Natural behavior, senses, training psychology, and common behavioral problems of horses. Equine welfare issues.
ANS225.restrictions: Open to undergraduate students or agricultural technology students.

ANS230.name: Dairy Herd Management
ANS230.description: Analysis of dairy farm management. Investigation and problem solving. Collecting data and formulating conclusions and recommendations. Oral presentation. Field trip required.
ANS230.restrictions: Open to students in the Institute of Agricultural Technology.

ANS232.name: Introductory Dairy Cattle Management
ANS232.description: Principles and techniques of dairy herd management including calf and heifer care plus lactating and dry cow management.

ANS233.name: Dairy Feed Management
ANS233.description: Feeding management of dairy cattle with emphasis on milking cows and replacements. Cost considerations of nutrient sources and supplies. Use of homegrown feeds. By-product utilization. Field trip required.
ANS233.restrictions: Open to students in the Institute of Agricultural Technology.

ANS235.name: Dairy Herd Reproduction
ANS235.description: Application of reproductive principles to dairy production. Field trip required.
ANS235.restrictions: Open to students in the Institute of Agricultural Technology.

ANS238.name: Dairy Health Management
ANS238.description: Detection of dairy cattle disease. Infections and metabolic problems.
ANS238.restrictions: Open to students in the Institute of Agricultural Technology.

ANS240.name: Horse Farm Management
ANS240.description: Integration of principles and skills into a farm management system. Managerial qualities, goal setting, facilities management. Health programs.
ANS240.restrictions: Open to students in the Institute of Agricultural Technology.

ANS242.name: Introductory Horse Management
ANS242.description: Principles of horse management. Reproduction, nutrition, herd health, genetics, economics, marketing.

ANS243.name: Horse Nutrition and Feeding
ANS243.description: Nutrient requirements of the horse, selection and evaluation of feedstuffs, balancing diets by hand and by computer, pasture management.
ANS243.restrictions: Open to students in the Institute of Agricultural Technology.

ANS244.name: Horse Facility Design and Management
ANS244.description: Equine facility design and management. Manure, pasture, and biosecurity management.

ANS245.name: Horse Exercise Physiology
ANS245.description: Horse body systems, physiology of exercise and conditioning programs. Goals of various conditioning programs. Common ailments of sport horses.
ANS245.restrictions: Open to students in the Institute of Agricultural Technology.

ANS247.name: Horse Health
ANS247.description: Health risks for horses, emergency care, preventive health care.

ANS248.name: Horse Reproductive Technology and Breeding Techniques
ANS248.description: Horse reproductive anatomy, physiology, breeding and foaling management.

ANS252.name: Introduction to Management of Avian Species
ANS252.description: Management of commercial poultry flocks and aviaries. Feed requirements, reproduction, breeding, housing and disease.

ANS272.name: Introductory Swine Management
ANS272.description: Swine production principles, practices, technologies, and systems. Field trip required.

ANS282.name: Companion Animal Biology and Management
ANS282.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
ANS282.description: Principles of companion animal management. Breeds, reproduction, feeding, housing, health, and diseases.

ANS290.name: Independent Study in Agricultural Technology
ANS290.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
ANS290.restrictions: Open to students in the Institute of Agricultural Technology.

ANS295.name: Structure and Function of Livestock
ANS295.description: Gross anatomy of livestock. Functions of tissues and organs. Regulation of growth, lactation, reproduction, seasonality, and temperature.
ANS295.restrictions: Open to students in the Institute of Agricultural Technology.

ANS300A.name: Advanced Livestock Judging
ANS300A.description: Evaluation of conformation and performance records of beef cattle, swine and sheep. Represent MSU in intercollegiate competition. Field trips required.
ANS300A.restrictions: Not open to freshmen. A student may earn a maximum of 8 credits from the following courses

ANS300C.name: Advanced Dairy Cattle Judging
ANS300C.description: Evaluation of conformation of various breeds of dairy cattle. Represent MSU in intercollegiate competition. Field trips required.
ANS300C.restrictions: Not open to freshmen. A student may earn a maximum of 8 credits from the following courses

ANS300D.name: Advanced Horse Judging
ANS300D.description: Evaluation of functional characteristics of horses. Represent MSU in intercollegiate competition. Field trips required.
ANS300D.restrictions: Not open to freshmen. A student may earn a maximum of 8 credits from the following courses

ANS300E.name: Animal Welfare Judging
ANS300E.description: Enhanced understanding of the physiological and behavioral indicators of animal welfare. Ethical values in the assessment of welfare status. Intercollegiate competition. Field trip required.
ANS300E.restrictions: Not open to freshmen. A student may earn a maximum of 8 credits from the following courses

ANS300F.name: Advanced Dairy Farm Evaluation
ANS300F.description: Evaluation of factors important in successful management of a dairy farm business. Represent Michigan State University in intercollegiate competition. Field trips required.
ANS300F.restrictions: Not open to freshmen or sophomores. Approval of department. A student may earn a maximum of 8 credits from the following courses

ANS301.name: Professional Development in Animal Science II
ANS301.description: Career preparation in animal science. Job interviewing skills. Oral presentation, written communication, and critical evaluation of science literature.
ANS301.prerequisite: (ANS 101 and ANS 110) and completion of Tier I writing requirement
ANS301.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the Department of Animal Science.

ANS305.name: Applied Animal Behavior
ANS305.description: Techniques for assessing health and welfare of domestic animals based on their behavior.

ANS305L.name: Applied Animal Behavior Laboratory
ANS305L.description: Biological basis of behavior to improve animal health, productivity and welfare.

ANS307.name: Animal Reproduction
ANS307.description: Reproductive physiology of farm and companion animals. Comparative reproduction in human and laboratory animals.

ANS309.name: Animal Health and Disease Management
ANS309.description: Normal and abnormal physical parameters. Common diseases. Role of housing, husbandry, sanitation, and animal treatment.
ANS309.prerequisite: ANS 110 and (BS 161 or LB 145 or BS 181H)

ANS313.name: Principles of Animal Feeding and Nutrition
ANS313.description: Comparative nutrition and metabolism for production, health, and stewardship of cattle, horses, swine, poultry, dogs and cats. Diet evaluation and formulation. Feeding management.
ANS313.prerequisite: ((BS 161 or LB 145 or BS 181H) and completion of Tier I writing requirement) and ((CEM 143 or concurrently) or (CEM 251 or concurrently))

ANS314.name: Genetic Improvement of Domestic Animals
ANS314.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
ANS314.description: Molecular, Mendelian, population, and quantitative genetics of domestic animals.
ANS314.prerequisite: ((BS 161 or BS 181H or LB 145) and completion of Tier I writing requirement) and (STT 200 or STT 201 or STT 421 or STT 464 or STT 231)

ANS315.name: Anatomy and Physiology of Farm Animals
ANS315.description: Gross and microanatomy of farm animals. Structure directed function of tissues. Endocrine integration for homeostasis. Regulation of growth, lactation, and reproduction. Homeorhesis.
ANS315.prerequisite: (BS 161 or LB 145 or BS 181H) and completion of Tier I writing requirement

ANS368.name: Zoo Animal Biology and Conservation
ANS368.description: Captive animal biology including illustrated examples of care, behavioral welfare and conservation work.
ANS368.prerequisite: BS 162 or LB 144 or BS 182H or approval of department

ANS401.name: Ethical Issues in Animal Agriculture
ANS401.description: Ethical issues related to local, national, and international animal agriculture.

ANS404.name: Introduction to Quantitative Genetics
ANS404.description: Theories and applications of quantitative genetics and their roles in breeding.
ANS404.prerequisite: (ANS 314) and (STT 200 or STT 201 or STT 231 or STT 421 or STT 464)

ANS407.name: Food and Animal Toxicology
ANS407.description: Fate and effects of chemicals in the food chain. Impact on animal production. Residues in food products. Food safety assessment. Control methods.

ANS409.name: Problems, Controversies and Advancements in Reproduction
ANS409.description: Selected topics in endocrine, cellular, molecular and genetic aspects of sex differentiation, gametogenesis, folliculogenesis, sexual cycles, behavior, fertilization, early embryo development, pregnancy, parturition, infertility, reproductive disorders, assisted reproductive technologies in humans, livestock and animal models.

ANS413.name: Non-Ruminant Nutrition
ANS413.description: Digestive processes and nutrient metabolism in non-ruminant animals. Metabolic basis for nutrient requirements.
ANS413.prerequisite: (ANS 110 and ANS 313) and (STT 200 or STT 201 or STT 464)
ANS413.restrictions: Not open to freshmen or sophomores.

ANS418.name: Animal Agriculture and the Environment
ANS418.description: Comprehensive nutrient management plans (CNMP) for animal feeding operations. Trends in animal production, environmental issues, and diet formulation and their impact on manure production. Development of CNMP for a specific animal feeding operation.
ANS418.prerequisite: (BS 161 or LB 145 or BS 181H) and (CEM 143 or CEM 251)

ANS422.name: Advanced Beef Cattle Feedlot Management
ANS422.description: Feedlot management systems and issues. Feed systems, manure management, health maintenance, and cattle marketing. Field trips required.
ANS422.restrictions: Not open to freshmen or sophomores.

ANS424.name: Sustainable Agriculture and Food Systems: Integration and Synthesis
ANS424.description: Biogeochemical and socio-economic aspects of food, fiber, and fuel production. Environmental impacts and social context. Experiential learning projects.
ANS424.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors or graduate students.

ANS425.name: Animal Biotechnology
ANS425.description: Application of molecular biology concepts to the improvement of domestic animals. Transgenic animal production, molecular genetics and marker assisted selection, animal cloning, Epigenetics, Assisted Reproductive Technologies (ART).
ANS425.prerequisite: (BS 161 or BS 181H or LB 145) and (CEM 143 or CEM 251)

ANS427.name: Environmental Toxicology and Society
ANS427.description: Impact of environmental chemicals on health and modern society. Cellular and organ functions and their interface with the environment. Limitations of scientific investigation and environmental regulations.

ANS430.name: Dairy Systems Management
ANS430.description: Decision-making strategies for dairy farms. Emphasis on herd replacements, personnel, health, facilities, nutrient management and other issues associated with dynamic markets and business environments. Field trips required.
ANS430.restrictions: Not open to freshmen or sophomores.

ANS432.name: Advanced Dairy Cattle Management
ANS432.description: Management techniques for operating a dairy herd. Mastitis control, reproductive and nutrition management, records, and general herd health. Field trips required.
ANS432.restrictions: Not open to freshmen or sophomores.

ANS433.name: Food Processing: Muscle Foods
ANS433.description: Manufacturing practices and principles of fresh, frozen, and cured meats and fish. Processed products from muscle foods. Product formulation and quality control.
ANS433.restrictions: Not open to freshmen or sophomores.

ANS435.name: Mammary Physiology
ANS435.description: Anatomy of the mammary gland and physiology of lactation in domestic and laboratory mammals. Mammary gland health and factors affecting lactation. Dairy herd milking management. Field trips required.
ANS435.prerequisite: (BS 161 or LB 145 or BS 181H) and (ANS 313 and ANS 315)
ANS435.restrictions: Not open to freshmen and not open to sophomores.

ANS442.name: Advanced Horse Management
ANS442.description: Management of stables and breeding farms. Pedigree and conformational selection, reproduction. Promotion, marketing, economics. Nutrition and feeding, facilities, and herd health.
ANS442.restrictions: Not open to freshmen or sophomores.

ANS445.name: Equine Exercise Physiology
ANS445.description: Research in equine exercise science. Physical, physiologic, metabolic and mental adaptation to athletic training. Nutrition and bioenergetics of muscle metabolism.

ANS455.name: Avian Physiology
ANS455.description: Systemic and comparative physiology of birds
ANS455.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors or graduate students.

ANS461.name: Seminar in Plant, Animal and Microbial Biotechnology
ANS461.description: Current applications of plant, animal and microbial biotechnology in agriculture and related industries. Technologies under development and factors associated with moving from laboratory to product development. Field trips required.
ANS461.prerequisite: (ANS 425 or concurrently) or (BE 360 or concurrently) or (CSS 451 or concurrently) or (MMG 445 or concurrently)

ANS464.name: Statistics for Biologists
ANS464.description: Biological random variables. Estimation of population parameters. Testing hypotheses. Linear correlation and regression. Analyses of counted and measured data to compare several biological groups including contingency tables and analysis of variance.
ANS464.prerequisite: MTH 103 or MTH 110 or MTH 116 or MTH 132

ANS472.name: Advanced Swine Management
ANS472.description: Management techniques for operating a swine herd. Management of reproduction and nutrition, records, and general herd health. Integration of husbandry and business principles for decision making.
ANS472.restrictions: Not open to freshmen or sophomores.

ANS480.name: Animal Systems in International Development
ANS480.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
ANS480.description: Animal systems in various global regions. Output, land and resource conservation, and socio-economic factors.
ANS480.restrictions: Not open to freshmen. Approval of department; application required.

ANS482.name: Advanced Companion Animal Management
ANS482.description: Companion animal behavior, welfare, anatomy, physiology, nutrition and health. Careers in the companion animal industry. Experiential learning projects. Field trip required.

ANS483.name: Ruminant Nutrition
ANS483.description: Nutrition, physiology and metabolism in ruminants. Prehension, digestion, metabolism, absorption, and distribution of nutrients for productive functions. Feeding management strategies and diet formulation. Field trip may be required.
ANS483.restrictions: Not open to freshmen or sophomores.

ANS490.name: Independent Study
ANS490.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
ANS490.description: Independent study in genetics, nutrition, physiology, toxicology, meat science, or management of poultry, livestock, or horses.
ANS490.restrictions: Not open to freshmen. Approval of department; application required.

ANS492.name: Undergraduate Research in Animal Science
ANS492.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
ANS492.description: Faculty supervised research in selected areas of animal science.
ANS492.prerequisite: (BS 161 or LB 145 or BS 181H) and (CEM 143 or CEM 251) and (ANS 313 or ANS 314 or ANS 315)
ANS492.restrictions: Not open to freshmen or sophomores. Approval of department; application required.

ANS493.name: Professional Internship in Animal Science
ANS493.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
ANS493.description: Supervised professional experience in the animal industry.
ANS493.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the Animal Science Major. Approval of department; application required. A student may earn a maximum of 6 credits in all enrollments for any or all of these courses

ANS511.name: Animal Science for Veterinarians
ANS511.description: Husbandry of domestic, laboratory, and zoo animals. Managerial systems in animal agriculture. Production and management goals.
ANS511.restrictions: Open only to graduate-professional students in the College of Veterinary Medicine.

ANS804.name: Introduction to Quantitative Genetics
ANS804.description: Theories and applications of quantitative genetics. Mutations, recombination, selection, and their roles in shaping genetic variation and covariance in idealized and finite populations.

ANS805.name: Animal Welfare Assessment
ANS805.description: Multidisciplinary online computer-based instruction in animal welfare science and related issues including physiology, behavior, human-animal interactions, suffering and pain, ethics, health, assessment and standards, and economics.

ANS814.name: Advanced Statistics for Biologists
ANS814.description: Concepts of reducing experimental error for biological and agricultural research. Covariance, randomized block designs, latin squares, split plots, repeated-measures designs, regression applications, and response surface designs. Analyses using statistical software.

ANS815.name: Advanced Topics in Reproduction and Development
ANS815.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
ANS815.description: Core concepts in animal reproduction and development. Recent advances relevant to animal and human fertility, development, and diseases.

ANS816.name: Integrative Toxicology: Mechanisms, Pathology and Regulation
ANS816.description: Biochemical, molecular, and physiological mechanisms of toxicology. Functional and pathological responses of major organ systems to chemical insult. Mechanisms of mutagenesis, carcinogenesis, and reproductive toxicology. Concepts in risk and safety assessment.

ANS823.name: Grant Writing for Biomedical Research
ANS823.description: Best practices for development, preparation and submission of competitive grant proposals for biomedical research.

ANS824.name: Methods in Quantitative Genomics
ANS824.description: Storage, processing and analysis of genotypic and phenotypic data using R. Basic R programming and R tools for genomic analyses. Genome-wide association studies and genomic prediction.

ANS828.name: Scientific Communication for Reproductive and Developmental Biology
ANS828.description: Best practices for preparing and delivering effective scientific seminars in reproductive and developmental biology.

ANS849.name: Applied Bayesian Inference using Monte Carlo Methods for Quantitative Biologists
ANS849.description: Applications of Bayesian inference using software in quantitative biology and genetics. Hierarchical and non-hierarchical models. Model checking, model selection and model comparison. Markov chain Monte Carlo methods.

ANS885.name: Animal Science Seminar
ANS885.description: Critical review of relevant literature and organization of communication of scientific data in animal science.
ANS885.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Animal Science.

ANS890.name: Advanced Independent Study
ANS890.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
ANS890.description: Investigation of topics of special interest.

ANS898.name: Master's Research
ANS898.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
ANS898.description: Scholarly project for non-thesis (Plan B) master's degree.
ANS898.restrictions: Open only to master's students in the Department of Animal Science. Approval of department; application required.

ANS899.name: Master's Thesis Research
ANS899.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
ANS899.restrictions: Open only to master's students in the Department of Animal Science. Approval of department.

ANS901.name: Selected Topics in Animal Breeding and Genetics
ANS901.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
ANS901.description: Selected topics of current interest and importance in animal breeding and genetics.

ANS924.name: Advanced Methods in Quantitative Genomics
ANS924.description: Artificial Intelligence applied to genomics, sequence and RNAseq analyses, gene enrichment and functional genomics, population genetics and phylogenetics with applications in livestock.

ANS936.name: Protein Nutrition and Metabolism
ANS936.description: Nutritional and endocrine regulation of protein synthesis and degradation, protein quality assessment, protein status, and protein-energy malnutrition. Protein metabolism during exercise. Metabolism, digestion, and absorption of amino acids and proteins.

ANS999.name: Doctoral Dissertation Research
ANS999.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
ANS999.restrictions: Open to doctoral students in the College of Agriculture and Natural Resources or in the Department of Animal Science. Approval of department.
